Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Clazomenian black-figured pottery dinos or krater: interior reserved; exterior: three black-figure friezes divided by single bands: top, siren to left (underbelly and legs remaining; added red and added white dots on wing); centre: two sirens to left (of that on left one outspread wing, with red and white dots and part of tail feathers, alternating red and white; that on right largely preserved (only tail feathers missing; white flesh, red and white dots on wing); below, water bird (only neck, head and one leg missing; red and white dots on feathers.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd possibly belongs to the same vase as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.43.1894. Also illustrated in Bourriau, J.D., Umm El-Ga`ab (1981) p. 84 no.163.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 38, no. 11, pl. XIX, no. 11)
Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 125, no. 14)
Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 61-2, pl. VIII, no. 2b)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.086) (phase 3)
